job_title: Financial Solutions Advisor in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Compensation was OKAY (but too little for southern California) and fancy corporate title was nice. Lots of vacation and sick time.
cons: 1 week of travel for training that was insufficient and could have been done via teleconference. Did not train me on how to properly recommend products. Advisers were not held accountable because there was not enough resources given to managers who were responsible for 20+ Advisers across a large territory. Documentation of client interactions were made in a system, however this means if there was a dispute it would be notes vs word of client, thusly making Adviser vulnerable to compliance violations. Systems were tedious, non-communicative to each other, and very very slow. Opening an account usually required 2-4 weeks and management was not understanding and often reminded Advisers that they could be fired and replaced. Bank duties were also expected by Advisers, however they often conflicted with Merrill Lynch goals since most banking business was time consuming and was not a part of quarterly metrics used to review Advisers. If an Adviser was okay at Banking and Investments, then he/she would get an okay quarterly review. If Adviser was great at Banking, then it was at the expense of Investments. If the Adviser was great at Investments and earned a large quarterly bonus at the expense of Banking, then he/she was not lauded for their Investments accomplishments. Rather he/she would be criticized for not doing enough Banking business. Pulled in many different directions by management. Also worked 45-55 hours per week including long driving travels to meetings. I was advised late in my tenure that some of these could be compensated for. When I found out, it was already too late to submit requests for compensation.

If you’re an experience advisor, stay away from this company - BANK OF AMERICA/MERRILL EDGE.

review_title: Excellent idea for getting paid to be licensed and recieve "rudimentary" training in securities work
pros:
Pay for training - Licensing
Provide training - Sales cycle
Provide training - Tools so you can instruct yourself after their training drops off
Great Benefits
Excellent comeraderay first few months of production
Improves your sense of humor
cons: When first entering production, it becomes quickly apparent that there is really no viable way for almost any participants to make sales quota - unless they can be successful at selling insurance (annuities), or derivatives (structured notes) - neither of which are ever really understood by the purchaser.  And you have to pay your franchisee, Merrill, for invitations to "seminars" where you say very little to nothing about what you know - and "seminars" are expensive to conduct even $3000k out of pocket for a good one.  The sales training is great - get them in the door - then who cares where their money goes.  And if you need help from an internal "specialist", be prepared to give up alot of what would have been your production.  If you are going to really try and start a career here, and stay here, then make sure it goes into those annuties, or structured notes, or C shares or A shares - all of which are illiquid to a great extent, are underperforming in the case of the first 2, and prevent you from taking those clients with you when you fail quota.  Oh, and don't let me forget Merrill is now a banking product originator!  Yeah, you are increasingly required to cross-sell Bank of America banking products, which are even lower pay out when they do pay out (you don't get credit until the following quarter), and if you don't do it then contractually Merrill can withhold any of your variable compensation including quarterly and annual bonuses, which eventually are supposed to make up a substantial part of your pay out.  Finally, be prepared to be treated like a dog by your sales manager and PMD coach - they don't do this for a living, they'll remind you of that repeatedly, and they'll tell you again and again you don't work hard enough, your a slouch, they don't care if you make it....  But let's revisit Pros before you talk yourself out of it -- they pay for great training, benefits are great, and lots and lots of people go through it with you.  Come to think of it, it's sort of like securities industry boot-camp.  Well then again if you tell your direct reports in boot camp you don't care if they make, you'll be deemed unfit for command... Just remember to deploy in, get your training, then extract at an opportune time if you actually want to have a rewarding career in this business.  Or, who knows, maybe you will make it and make $120k a year by 4th year.  It's possible, just not probable.

1. Workers who will never conform to updates/changes/technological advances etc. If you try and automate a process, people fear they will lose their jobs. In most cases it's true. So instead of learning and making processes better, you hear "this is the way it's always been done".
2. Management has no clue about your day to day work responsibilities. You can't ask them anything because they can't give you an answer on how to solve a problem because they wouldn't know where to start.

4. If you're part of the 20%, of workers, you get scrutinized for reporting too much overtime when you are swamped with work. You can't report this to your superviser because they probably won't care, and will scrutinize you.
5. If you are part of the 20% of workers, imagine taking direction from somoene who barely knows how to use excel but is your "superior"
6. Don't think that by being part of the 20% who does more work gets praised more. Actually, quite the opposite. You set yourself up for more criticism. If you're part of the 80% of lazy people who do menial tasks but you do them well, you will be praised.

job_title: Banking Center Manager II in Kansas City, MO
pros: The benefits were great. The position also provided great work/life balance and the pay was good.
cons:
The onboarding was horrendous.  The time was mostly spent in front of a computer with training modules for 3 months.  The branch manager I was shadowing was supposed to be much more hands on with my training; however, the cut backs in staffing prevented this from happening.  This lead to many questions and trial by error once in the actual position itself.

At the market manager level, there were many false promises and lack of insight to issues at hand.  The overall message was to perform at a high level at all costs and concerns were ignored.  There was no guidance from my manager and morale overall was very low for the market.  Praise was rarely given, but criticism was delivered often.

Through the brilliance of cutting back on staffing, this caused many branches to run a skeleton crew.  If one person called of sick, it caused a major disruption in the performance of the center on that particular day and there was little to no hope of getting help anywhere else.  Cut backs on staffing also raised the risk of becoming less operationally sound and an increase probabliy of internal and external risk.  As staff members quit, in many cases, branches had to run with just 1 teller opreating both lobby and drive through.  These tellers had no time for breaks.  I am not sure why there were not more OSHA complaints filed.   All the while, there was the constant pressure of performing at a high level which demoralized staff.

I would not recommend anyone to apply to Bank of America from the outside into any management position.  Tragically, it is a corporation in every sense of the word.  Market managers press very hard and take little into consideration the circumstances each branch faced.  While there is a statement that people matter, in truth, money and performance matters above all else.  Unless the mangement styles drastically changes putting the focus back on staffing and people, stay away from this bank.  Better opportunities lie with other organizations.

job_title: Home Services Specialist in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Good benefits. There are opportunities for positions/jobs available.
cons:
While I feel like the company itself is OK to work for, I think the Home Service Specialist position is probably the worst position at Bank of America. Somehow, they have found a way to turn the Processors into Underwriters without the title or pay. The processors have too many responsibilities placed upon them, which makes it nearly impossible to be successful. I have lost count of the amount of people taking "stress leave". I have also never seen so many people being written up for ridiculous things that they have little control over. 

Leaders (over the team leads) seem very out of touch with what the processors have to deal with on a daily basis as they sit in their offices all day. They ask for feedback and when feedback is given, they get defensive and dismiss any concerns. 

There are also many huddles, meetings, trainings, and other miscellaneous things that interrupt the day and make it impossible to get all work done. Then you get management wondering why you didn't finish your work for the day. They also wonder why no one wants to participate in the occasional "fun" activities they have scheduled. It's because processors are overworked and too stressed to participate!

A processor will be expected to collect/review an almost constant stream incoming documents, review up to 4-5 new applications a day, keep the client "informed", answer incoming calls, deal with escalations, resolve title issues, and “decision” at last 2 applications a day (amongst many other things). They are also expected to complete income reviews, even though the underwriter will basically disregard it and re-write it themselves. 

The processors don’t mind working hard, but the size of the "pipeline" (number of applications assigned to processors at one time) is too high which makes it nearly impossible to complete the work that is expected. You are often left feeling very defeated at the end of the day.

Also, forget about vacation or calling in sick without having to worry about if your workload will be taken care of. There is not enough coverage to properly handle the out of offices, so you will spend the next week trying to catch up. Coming back from vacation is also stressful, as your pipeline gets depleted while you are out; which means you are going to be pushed more new applications than you can handle in one day. 

Incentives (bonuses) are not great and are structured in a way that is too complicated to understand. 

I would not recommend this position to anyone. There are a lot of improvements and adjustments that need to be made, but leaders seem unwilling to make necessary changes.

job_title: Senior IT Consultant in Chandler, AZ
pros: Benefits are some of the best in the market.  If you are in a niche position you will have innovative freedom and ability to complete tasks unhindered.
cons:
'Cultures' are pushed on everyone with emphasis on innovation and communication.  None of which are promoted, nor accepted outside of these training sessions.  If you have a new innovative way to do a process you will be shot down from multiple higher levels before it even gets anywhere.  Reasoning is that if you developed a better way to do something you will take work away from those that spend lots of time doing  a task a mundane, slow, and banal way.  Stagnation in your role, with no way to move up, is essentially the life in BofA.  Ambition is punished.  

Many people were laid off recently May and June 2017.  The year began with substantial gains and the CEO stated that the firm is growing with no risk of lay offs on the horizon. SVP stated the same, especially to production IT environments.  This is smoke in your face since over 900 production IT employees were laid off a few months later.  My position, as well as two others on my team, was laid off due to a reason of 'staffing reduction'.  Not even two weeks later and personnel from another declining team were shifted into these roles, filling the same exact positions and responsibilities.  The new personnel have zero experience in the position, need to be severely trained and supervised, and are actually paid more than the prior team members.  Does that sound fair or even smart to you?

Due to HR incompetence, IT positions that were initially hired in a non-IT campus, such as Chandler, AZ, leave a person with zero ability at chances of being re-hired if they're laid off.  HR managers do not and will not contact a manager that has an available IT position at several national sites to determine if Chandler is an option.  HR looks at the spec sheet, Chandler is not listed there, and the answer is "no, it's not available in Chandler or Phoenix."  We all know that a telecommute position, or a national position, can be done in Chandler or Phoenix - why screw over former workers by allowing your HR people to be so lazy and not in any way assist former employees?  BofA states caring, culture, compassion, and understanding, but it is all B.S., especially when you're laid off and HR won't even check to see if a position can be done at another corporate site.

Lastly, consider 1% raises to be the norm if you're in the upper specrum of pay for your position.  Even if you work more, have more responsibility, the lower staff in your team will receive 3%, 5%, or higher per year while a person with much more experience and responsibility is shunned.

review_title: The Good, the bad and the descpicable of working for Bank of America.
pros: They have a great package for new parents, both men and women- lots of time off with the new baby...although I never utilized it. Depending on what department you work in the office space can be pretty and can make you feel good about being there. The money was great and each year the company met its goal, employees got a bonus sometimes in time for Christmas. If you're single and you want to travel, this is definitely the company for you- you'll go to really nice towns...lots considered tourist spots.  They always, always put their employees in the best hotels...no motels here!  They have lots of choices in healthcare plans but you have to pay a portion.
cons: One of the biggest downsides for me was being embarassed about predatory lending practice news stories that came out one after the other.  I found it difficult to look at people struggling to stay afloat knowing how much money the company wastes; i.e. staying at the best hotels in great cities, they'd even pay for extra night or two if it was your first time to that particular city (of course that depended a lot on who approved your travel).  One of the thing that I didn't like was the backstabbing- I walked out with an entire cutlery set in back when all was said and done.  A lot of the backstabbing wasn't even to get an immediate reward- it was just learned behavior with the thought that stepping on your back might help them later or might make them look better to a bigger boss...and I really emphasize might.  People were taking credit for other's work whenever they could get away with it.  That seems petty looking back on it but in the moment it can be unnerving. My workload was way too much for one person and if you ask for help- well, just don't ask.  All the good things you learned about being a good, respectful and courteous employee...throw them out of the window. People are only respectful and courteous if they need you or if they're going to look bad in front of their and your peers, otherwise, it is completely ingenuine.  The proof will be when they act like they don't know when they move to another team and they will because that's what they do...people are always, always moving from team to team.  Work is often duplicated, sometimes triplicated because the one employee that knows where something is is not around.  There's a lot of that- one person hogging the knowledge for job security then pushing the blame off on you because you're not learning quick enough.  Well, I think that is a fairly good primer.  Oh one more thing, the employees just have a general nasty, mean tone and attitude.  It made me very unhappy to have to deal with that.

review_title: Not all that it appears to be
job_title: Customer Service & Sales II in Scranton, PA
pros: Employee discounts, nice cafeteria, co-workers are supportive
cons: In reading the first several pages of reviews, it appears B of A is a great place to work...It might be if you are not in a call center or higher up on the 'food chain' with the company, as were some that posted reviews.  As for employment in a call center at B of A, it is not all that great.  When hired I was told holidays were alternated between sites- haven't had a holiday off yet, unless it was a scheduled day off.  Sure, they pay you for the day, whether or not you worked but it would be really nice to spend a holiday with my family.  Upon hire they give you 3 weeks vacation- trying to take the time is a real chore.  Then they have this thing called occurances that is associated with your sick time- so whether you take one day or 4 consecutive days off sick it is counted a one occurance.  That means if you call off sick on Monday go to work on Tueday then call off sick on Wednesday- that counts as two occurances.  After so many, they will fire you...strange set up.  During your scheduled work hours- you are timed everytime you log off to go the bathroom- if you are gone too long, you will be told to take if off your next break~ I understand this is against labor laws.  Be prepared to be tied to your desk and monitored on everything you do from the time you step foot in the door..It is true that nobody in this company is on the same page; you can ask four different managers the same question and you will get four different answers. I find the majority of management is not what you would expect- the women are the worst.  My advice is if you decide to take a position at B of A- stay out of the Customer Serivce and Sales department- what is expected of an employee in this department in truly unreasonable.  Do not buy into the 'incentive' ploy- very few get incentive, practices and procedures are at times, unethical.  Yes, there is room for advancement, however you need to be with the company for at least 1 year before you can apply for another position within the company- note: you have to apply- you will not be promoted. Work environment is quite ridgid; I find it to be an unhealthy environment all around.

job_title: Technology Associate in New York, NY
pros:
I was in the Technology Associate Program (TAP) at Bank of America for a little over a year and a half. I'm writing this review because I wasn't able to find one when I joined.

Some pros:
1.) If you're interested in finance, it's not a bad place to be. BofA is a recognizable name and the program is supposedly well regarded.

2.) Most of the people I worked with were friendly and enjoyable to be around. 

3.) The hours are reasonable - everyone I worked with left work by 6 pm everyday. If you aren't based in NYC, it's probably earlier than that.

4.) 15 days of vacation is pretty good for finance, especially when you've just graduated from college.
cons:
Oh, the cons. There are many.

1.) They continue to pay the class of TAPs the following year more money without offering the same realignment to the current class. For instance, the 2014 and 2015 TAPs in NYC were paid 71k. In 2016, they were paid 85k. I left before hearing about the 2017s, but because BofA is trying to be competitive with Goldman and JP, it's likely more.

2.) When you're promoted to AVP in two years, you (probably) won't get a significant raise.  You will only get a raise if you have another offer from another company.

3.) They try to claim that they "teach" you finance, but the reality is that most trading desks are more complex beyond what they teach you in training. It will take 6 months to a year to feel like you're actually doing any work. 

4.) You have absolutely no say as to what team you will end up on. If you end up on a Front Office facing team that uses Quartz, great! You'll get more visibility and probably more money if you stay there for years, and valuable experience since Python and Quartz are in-demand skills. But, if you end up on a Back Office team or doing ASD (support) work, you won't get much exposure or transferable skills and will be stuck at BofA forever. Trust me, the recruiting teams will try to convince you otherwise, but the reality is that a significant number of TAPs end up in a back office role on a team that has nothing to do with trading.

5.) If you're female or white or both, you will be in the very, very vast minority unless they're now able to attract a higher caliber of candidate with the increased salary. Most people in the program are Asian males. 

Really glad I was able to get out of this place. The TAP program allowed me to get my foot in the door in NYC, but once I realized that I wouldn't advance at all, I got the skills I wanted and got out. If you're desperate enough to take their offer, I encourage you to do the same.

pros:
I worked for Bank of America as a relationship banker for two years and I am writing this review now two years later after my employment there. Total time in the banking industry I have is 5 years combined.
For  the pros while working at the Ojai branch in California I will say most co-workers were supportive. The job responsibilities and goals were realistic and the pay was okay once you're a relationship banker or above.
cons:
Since this is a job in the banking industry I will highlight that the regulations & compliances are many and while this clear to see it is hard to keep up with since rules are always changing. To explain the complexity of it I will say this bank even has a data base of rules which you have to check weekly on how to conduct business and how to handle thing. It takes a long time to learn some of this and the steps to do things right are MANY not to mention they change constantly. 

Your job can easily be taken away without any warning, like in my case. what's more when you start employment here they make you sign a paper giving them all the right to terminate you at any point in time if they wish to. Without your signature and approval to that rule you cannot start employment here. Because of this they have all the rights to fire you the same day without any interest in your personal life even if they are wrong, so beware!

This happens all the time even to someone with a lot of experience in the banking industry, that's why banks and employers freak out every time there's an audit. Audits happen once every year and they are surprise visits at any time without warning. 
My advice to you is be very careful and take your time (and I mean take your time) doing your work if you decide to go in this industry, but if you do then have a plan B and a good savings account just in case ready because the next person out of a job without a reason could be you.

The benefits at Bank of America are great!  They offer Child Care Reimbursement, $1 for $1- 401k match up to 5%,  and a company sponsored Health Care Reimbursement account.  Let's not forget the Federally observed paid holidays.
cons: Bank of America  tries to micromanage everything.   There is definitely a lack of support for those directly working with the customer.  Little recognition for actually providing exceptional service.  It all becomes a game of making the numbers.   This in turn rewards associates for getting customers into products they do not need and are rewarded by the company.   Although the Bank likes to view itself as a "store of products" and their bankers as "sellers, "   the bank dismisses in my opinion  a greater responsibility to provide an honest, upfront service for its customers.  The market management never gets involved in helping customers.  They come in the branch, cross their legs, and make their almighty genius observations.   There might be a line out the door and they do not do anything but sit and play around on their Blackberry.  What message does this send about the company's commitment to customer service?   It is no surprise they are repeat winners of the  2007 and 2008 "Hall of Shame," for customer service ranked by MSN Money.  Despite the fact they are Bank, open the same hours  - day in and day out,  and the expected staffing levels are predictable, countless time is spent on a scheduling application trying to figure how to staff. The scheduling program reminds me of HAL in the film 2001.  Let's just say HAL malfunctions on a regular basis and in the end a 15 page schedule comes out where every 1/2 hour of every associate's day assigned a 3 letter code as to what they are supposed to be doing.  The Bank entrust HAL to staff everything correctly and gives no empowerment for a center to adjust staffing levels as  needed.  I have never seen any company struggle so hard as to get something as simple as staffing down. Is it any surprise that all this complication results in understaffing, missed opportunity,  and poor service.  Emails and suggestions for improvement are mostly not even responded to and generally not welcome. To sum it up I would not recommend anyone I know to pursue a career with Bank of America.

pros: Assitance with day care, overall benefits are good.
cons:
This company is unethical in its promotional practices, uses deceit and favortism to promote their friends.  Experience counts for nothing.  Very difficult to work in environment that is extreamly stressful due to poor leadership skills. No committment to employees to treat them fairly.   Even with good benefits the stress and mismanagement will make your job unbearable.  Company culture has gone down the drain since 2009. After acquiring very Merrill & Countrywide, the friendly "let's help each other learn and grow to reach higher standards together" bank culture has been replaced with a "throw people under the bus" and "get ahead by any means, including making snap business decisions without considering consequences" culture. The company doesn't care as much for it's associates as they used to. The atmosphere is highly political, much more so than it was in the past. - The company is VERY disorganized and lacks in an integrated communication strategy even within individual business units. The right hand never knows what the left hand is doing, even within peer teams. We spend a lot of time fixing problems that we create internally (many due to poor decisions, or lack of communication).
- Company is too big, too complex, and extremely hard to navigate. There are many convoluted processes in place (like internal recruiting, compensation, & promotions) that the average associate does not understand. Like wise, the company is so big that it's very hard to know what's what organizationally & who's who, even within the smaller business units.
- Company does not require formal training for managers. Likewise, most associates are only required to take annual compliance training, but no formal on the job training. This often leads to entire teams not knowing/understanding and underperforming in their function within the process. A lot of associates and managers are set up for failure if they are not savvy enough to just "figure it out".
- Compensation/Promotions: The "lucky" associates that have the opportunity to work for great leaders may be fortunate enough to be paid in the appropriate range and recieve promotions based on capabilities and value add/leadership potential to the company. THIS VERY RARELY HAPPENS. More often then not, associates do not get timely promotions or raises. The associates who "play the game", but may do less or lower quality work will be be paid more than the guy who's really performing. Furthermore, all performance evaluations & rate increases, etc. are subjective based on the immediate manager. There is no consistency in how associates are rated, which leaves a lot of room for favoritism.
- The company overall has certain values and advocates specific things like (inclusive meritocrazy, and flexible work schedules) but all that depends on the immediate manager. If an associates immediate manager does not advocate the companies values, than the associate is out of luck. Likewise, there is no associate support to protect from bad/poor management. If an associate is dealing with an unfair manager, he/she has no true recourse of action (other than to call the internal HR Advice & Counsel hotline, which means nothing because all they will do is document for a case against the associate if the problem continues to compound).

review_title: There is no career growth with this company
pros: Competitive pay and benefits. Government holidays.
cons:
The micro-management really needs to stop. Everyone's performance affects the team's performance, but I get hounded by sales managers that aren't even responsible for my role (CSR - not that it matters what the role is called because customers will always call us tellers). Even though our job isn't necessarily to sell, we still get hounded daily to meet referral numbers. 

Also, don't count on ever being fully staffed. The turnover rate is ridiculous with this company - it's a literal revolving door. Teammates and managers alike change every other month, if they get replaced at all. They don't want to have more CSR's (tellers) in the branch so they can push digital banking, so there is often only one CSR (teller) that has to get yelled at by the customers about not having more people when there is a line out the door. Managers don't really help with career progression, so if you're seeking a career with this company, don't even bother.

On that note, this company lies about "encouraging internal growth." I have been seeking a different role in the company for four months already, and it's not like I'm un-qualified for the roles I am pursuing.  But I get rejected at every turn because the company wants to bring in people from the outside. The company wants to trap associates in the financial center, propagating this lie that the only career path for someone who starts off as a CSR (teller) is to be a personal banker, then an assistant manager, and finally a financial center manager. This company has several lines of business, so it's ridiculous that it keeps pushing this idea that the only jobs it wants filled are in the financial centers.

If an accomplishment was acknowledged at all, it was a brief 10 second bunching together on a conference call, and there was never genuine personalized thanks. If a mistake occurred, we heard about it for weeks, if not months in every email, in huddle material, on conference calls... Very negative reinforcement oriented.  The recruiters lure you in with potential bonuses as though they are on top of the base, but after a solid year, I saw they were part of the amount quoted as the base salary. Since we are expected to work every single Saturday of the year (half day), we were told we can have a half day off during the week... pros: Benefits were great, meet some great contacts

I worked in collections, when MBNA took over we were told to answer the phone as "FIA CARD SERVICES" and not to confirm we were BOA until after we had verified the customer the process was the same outbound. We were told what to do but when we ran into problems all our questions were placed in a "Packing Lot" & forgotten. Customers wanted to know what "FIA" stood for were were never told. (this is one example). I also did mortgage modification this became such a mess we had to create an escalation unit where I worked. Customer Relationship Managers (CRM) collected documents from the customer to be reviewed by Process Support (PS) who reviewed documents to send for a final review to an underwriter in another state. The PS would have contests to decision the accounts. They would be rewarded for either passing or failing a review this was done to get through the heavy workload which often meant they would at the last minuet just decline files by the caseload to get through them.  The workload was terrible. At another point I was promoted to Short-Sale Escalations and this was pretty much the same the workload was extremely high, stress was high and the goal was if you couldn't simply pass it get it declined and get rid of it. It did not feel like the right thing at the time and still makes me feel bad.. BOA would just make snap changes because they looked good on paper but never took into account any feed back from the people in the trenched doing the job. this only added to the insane workloads and stress.  I now work for a rival bank that puts allot into having a culture, they center on associates and customers and changing banking for good. BOA could really stand to learn something about that instead of bureaucracy.

pros: Cons far outweigh benefits. Take it from me and look elsewhere. I know several employees who left BOA to go to Capital One.
cons:
I worked for BOA for over 5 years before I quit. Former CEO was way better than current CEO. I didn't complain when BOA bought a new corporate jet rather than pay out bonuses to its Banking Center associates but their new strategy is ridiculous. If you wanted to get rid of 3k employees by 2016 you're doing an amazing job. 

Two tellers per banking center is ridiculous; So when one goes to lunch or much worse vacation, one teller is left to deal with a line out the door AND is expected to STILL make referrals and no differences. LISTEN TO YOUR CUSTOMERS. YOUR CUSTOMERS WANT MORE TELLERS. Whose bright idea was this really? If you're going to have two tellers and no drive-thrus at least stop cashing checks for non-customers. Instead of tellers giving great service to OUR customers we're spending time being check cashers. If you continue allowing non-account holders to cash checks at least charge them a fee like Chase or PNC does. Do you know Chase charges $7 for cashing checks for non-account holders? Extra revenue, less money you'll have to order... and the "un-bankable" as you like to call them won't be clogging up your lines. 

For PBs, the goals are so ridiculous that you have to lie, cheat and steal to meet goal. And you wonder why there's a problem with customers being issued credit cards that they never agreed to.  Also, whose bright idea was it to become a "Doctor's office" and not let your customers know???? And whose bright idea was it to not communicate this with other departments so that when, let's say some irresponsible drunk loses their card over the weekend, that the customer service associates don't offer to schedule them an appointment before they walk in? These same customers become very upset because this wasn't communicated and then they watch helplessly as someone who DID have an appointment is seen before them. I'd LOVE to meet who came up with this AMAZING idea! 

Also, very little room to grow, unless of course you're someone's favorite or you're pimping your body out to middle management.

pros:
1) You will learn a lot about the banks internal operations.

2) You will learn a lot on how a large multi-national operates and the complexities involved.

3) There is still some reluctant respect for Bank of America in the job market, so you will be popular with recruiters on LinkedIn

4) Most people in GT&O (Global Technology & Operations) are technically competent. Unfortunately this is offset by some of the cons below.

5) Decent benefits, although I can't compare with other companies. 100% match on 5% 401K match is generous.
cons:
1) I have seen a lot of Nepotism. It's tough to get a promotion if you don't spend time with your boss over the weekends, parties, don't speak the same language, or share the same culture etc. (That's the case with my Boss, can't speak for other teams). People who do, have a leg up over you. This happens not just at lower levels, but at higher levels as well. ( I know of at least one case at the SVP level. One or two instances don't mean the practice is rampant, but cockroaches don't come in ones and twos.). If you join an established team, don't expect promotions based on merit. Promotions here are based on tenure. If you do join, learn as much as you can and move on to better opportunities within 2-3 years.

2) Promotion process is very opaque. No feedback is given on why you were passed over for a promotion. Each manager above you will blame the manager above them. That seems to be the management practice: if you don't know the answer, or want to avoid uncomfortable conversations, blame your manager and say your hands are tied. All of this happens even after a very good performance review.

3) Traffic jam on the corporate ladder. When someone above you leaves or retires, then the traffic moves up. If you are caught in the wrong lane, tough luck. The technology division with updated technology can run well with half the workforce. 

4) Your merit will go unrecognized. Yes, you will get reward points and pats-on-the-back. But that rarely translates to promotions, better assignments or more responsibility.

5) The bank does nothing to identify it's next generation of technology leaders. On the operations side, each leader spent years in multiple lines of businesses before being considered for an executive level position. No such concept exists on the technology side. All technology divisions supporting the different lines of businesses are silos. The only way to work for a different organization would be to go through the limited number of opportunities on the career portal (not all positions are posted there), or to go through an EXTERNAL recruiter!!!!

6) The Bank doesn't really invest in making sure their workforce has updated skills. Yes, they do have a internal learning portal, but a technology organization doesn't remain strong by people learning via youtube like videos and internal webex presentations. Management has a budget for end-of-year parties, travel expenses, multiple times a year, but almost nothing for internal training. A lot of my peers would love to skip the parties for decent training.

7) Performance reviews are a joke. Most of the goals are not relevant to your job. Managers don't provide relevant and precise feedback on how to improve performance or how to get a promotion. I would rather get actionable constructive criticism everyday than a generic "good job" once a year. Managers don't know how to give such feedback, because they themselves never got such feedback.

8) There is frequent performance evaluation at the bank, but it's only unidirectional. Associates are evaluated on their performance twice a year by their managers. Associates get to evaluate their managers through anonymous surveys only once in two years. Managers are then held accountable to their results by appropriate goals the following year. So management is hearing the same message over and over again, and makes changes by being reactive and slow. They are trying to put band-aid on a wound today that needed to be cauterized 3 years ago.

9) There is a lot of inertia in the way the bank works and thinks. Multiple competing philosophies, of how technology needs to be delivered, exist and are not reconciled. The right hand does sometimes know what the left hand is doing, but the two hands are often speaking a different language.

pros: Compensation, vacation time (3 weeks to start), 401k, on-site gym (Simi Valley location), lots of security, flexible work schedule, relaxed dress code for people not working with the public.
cons:
My biggest concern was poor training.  I received "the bum's rush" each time I met with my trainer. The person who was training me clearly knew her job; however, she did not want to train me (I'm sure her workload could barely handle it); she had absolutely no personality and made me feel inferior with every question I had.  
Most of my work was done on spreadsheets.  I have the knowledge in Excel to perform my job; however, my trainer always started the session without explaining what we were doing.  It was basically: "click here; go here; put it here; and make sure they give you all the back-up.  Let me know if you have any questions."  She also told me that if I took notes it would slow her down too much so I had to try to commit everything to memory.  When I asked about timelines for projects, she just nodded her head.  What?
Only a few co-workers actually said to me "it's a lot to learn and will take awhile."  Other than that, I was made to feel like a complete idiot, of which I am not.  
My Supervisor was not available for questions I had.  My first week there she didn't speak with me.  (Yes, this is true.)  I was told by another team Supervisor that my Supervisor was new to that position, but come on ... if I were the Supervisor, I would probably check in a few times each day just to make sure everything was OK with the "new hire."  
Each time I asked her if I could speak with her, she was always "going into a meeting," "pressed for time," "have to make a phone call."  
I have a strong work ethic and do my job well.  I am not a person who needs constant supervision or constant pats on the back: I go to work; do my job; am confident; and am a well-liked coworker who enjoys being part of a team and am always ready to pitch in.  
I like to be busy at the office and have little patience for slackers so I really thought I would fit in at B of A, but it was a terrible experience.
It's really too bad because I would have been a valuable asset to the team.

There are high expectations to treat customers well and always with courtesy but managers do not treat employees that way.
Systems issues are rampant and delays or slow downs due o system problems are frequently used against associates either to deny commission payout or in performance reviews For example in April and May of 2014,  known call routing issues resulted in sales leads not going to hundreds of associates in multiple sites. Instead of explaining the problem, managers harassed their teams to perform. Daily reports status updates through 5/15 showed more than 1/2 of all associates were selling at the lowest levels. Then they stopped giving associates the daily reports but used what they said were accurate figures to harass them. This two month system issue caused high levels of stress amongst employees and loss of commission revenue. To date this issue has still not been acknowledged. 
They issue penalty points whenever associates take an earned sick day. Many people come to work sick when they have paid sick time available but too many penalty points to use it. This causes infectious illnesses like flu to breed in work centers. Again, loss of commission, stress, and the added problem of infected associates taking these germs home to family and friends.

I was offered a promotion and told I would have to do one interview with a manager I already had a relationship.  Instead, I had to go through three interviews and at each one I was told completely opposite descriptions of the promotion.  The first interview was supposed to be on the phone at 1pm. + Often move way to fast to implement projects just to get it done by some artificial deadline.  Very frustrating and is pervasive throughout the company.

-They do not value their employees. When the branch is busy you can forget about taking your scheduled breaks! Managers will force you to stay on the teller line until the line of customers dies down. However, most banks have specific high foot traffic times, meaning they have long lines everyday and at multiple times during the day. For example, upon opening for about 2 hours, during lunch time for about 2-3 hour,s and the hour before closing. There were many times (over the course of the year that I worked for B of A) where employees were forced to wait for hours to use the bathroom and stay over an hour late because of customers or other issues with their out of date and cheap systems etc.

-They will force you to present offers to customers on the teller line making customers feel like you're a door to door sales person when they simply wanted to pay a bill or make a deposit.
-Bank of America does not care if you have two days off in a row. Some people may be okay with this, but from my experience if you value your employees you will give them two days off in a row to have time to fully decompress and relax. This is so you can come back to work refreshed and in a positive frame of mind!
-From my experience I feel that the managers only care about numbers and sales. Employees were pushed daily but weren't supported to be able to make their goals.

I've seen so many qualified people lose out on positions just because the manager had a childish grudge against them, and that manager actually went out of his way to spread false rumors to the CMM and hiring managers just to make that candidate look bad. That manager instead would help employees who were his "friends" even though they had horrible sales numbers and help them get higher positions. Even though the manager I currently work with is horrible and tried to sabotage people's careers if they aren't on his good side, I have worked with other managers who have been amazing and truly care for their workers. Sadly, the number of bad managers overrides the number of good managers who actually try to nurture the growth of their employees. It's bad enough that Bank of America severely underpays its employees (we are one the lowest paid banks in the nation), but managers create an environment where work feels more like a prison. I also hate that as an organization, Bank of America is so disgustingly sales driven. They always say we need to look out for the customers best interest, and sell them a product. But if we know that the customer is going to suffer from extra debt and the product is going to obviously ruin their credit scores, managers don't care. As long as we get the sale it doesn't matter if we ruin that customer's life.

Mundane work - very operational entry-level work even for mid/senior management. The work is more about maintaining/overseeing processes rather than doing anything thought provoking. This also contributes to the rigid structure offering little career growth. 

Demanding yet uninspiring leaders. "My way or the high way" approach from leaders. They also tend to not be transparent with their teams. Some are known to be rude yet no one (HR) does anything about it. I'm talking about a lot of the executive committee members.

Salary and bonus is not particularly generous considering the company is showing record earnings. 

This is one of the worst company cultures I've seen  (can only speak for Hong Kong) despite global heads always talking about valuing people it's a shame Hong Kong is not doing this.
